content.description: Good beginner route.  Easy low angle face climb past bolts.  One person that made an early lead of this climb suggested the name "Disappearing Steps" because he said the good holds disappear around the last bolt.
content.location: This route and formation lies between the Rust Bucket and Mosspile formations.  It is located a few hundred yards east of the 29th street crag.

content.description: This route features two bulges, some poor rock at the bottom, and some excellent rock for the middle third of the route. Of the now 11 routes in the area, this is my favorite.
content.location: This route is to the right of Gilbert

content.description: The Ogden Area book by David Robb proclaims this the best route on the wall.  I would call it a tie between this route and Loose Shingles.  Great route with lots o' thin and crimpy (but positive) holds.
content.protection: 3 bolts to chains.  Accessible for top-rope if you belly over the edge.
content.location: 2nd route from the west on the more sheer face of the crag

content.description: Look for bolts that go up the face just left of the mossy portions of the face.  Start with face and a very shallow right facing corner, turning to slab near the top.
content.protection: Four bolts, bring a sling for the horn at the top.
content.location: This formation is located a few hundred yards east of the 29th street crag.  The climb is on the left end of the north-east face.

content.description: This route is basically just a 3 move boulder problem followed by easy climbing above.  The crux move involves pulling on a really sharp crimp just above the first bolt giving the route it's name.  Once you clip the second bolt, the route is basically over.
content.protection: Three bolts to the two bolt anchor shared with Safety Goggles.
content.location: This is the furthest left route on the wall, just to the left of Safety Goggles.

content.description: Good holds and a nice warm-up climb.  Some of the holds in the area are a little sharp and will leave your fingers sore.
content.protection: 2 bolts + chains at the top.  You can scramble up the west side to set a top rope.
content.location: First bolted climb on the west side of the crag.

content.description: The book claims this to be a 5.10d, however, I think it is closer to a 5.10b.  Fun roof at the beginning of the climb and another near the top.  Be sure to wear long pants and a shirt as the roofs are a little harsh on bare skin.  The upper roof is a little reachy for smaller folks like myself, but doable (if not pretty).
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains - top rope accessible from the west side of the crag
content.location: This is the right most climb that tackles the lower roof straight on.  First bolt is just past the roof with 2 more before the next roof.  There is a bolt just over the edge of the second roof, then an easy scramble to the chains at the top.

content.description: This is a good easy route that would work well for someone's first lead.  The climbing is fairly continuous (for a 30 foot route) at 5.7 without a distinct crux.  The rock is actually quite solid despite its chossy appearance.
content.location: New route between Safety Goggles and Overlooked.

content.description: Locate the bolt about 15 ft. up.  The route finishes up the small crack as the route eases to the top.
content.location: A few hundred feet south of the 29th st. Crag.

content.description: Just left of Rust Bucket.  It has some poor rock and is overall, a below average climb.  After clipping the last bolt near the top of the wall, angle up and right to the Rust Bucket Chains.
content.protection: 6 bolts, you could place gear between the 5th and 6th bolts

content.description: Easy start yields to a little more thought provoking climbing as you have to move around for better holds.  Good warm-up or 1st time lead climb - shares chains with Loose Shingles, but you can skirt the small roof near the top.
content.protection: 3 bolts to chains - top rope access from the west side of the crag.
content.location: Climb the obvious corner between the sheer face and the small roof near the ground.
